title: Quantum Entanglement in Many-Body Systems: A Tensor Network Approach
authors:
Alice Zhang¹, Bob Kumar², Carlos Mendez¹
¹Department of Physics, MIT
²Institute for Quantum Computing, University of Waterloo
affiliations:
¹Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139
²University of Waterloo, Waterloo, ON N2L 3G1, Canada

paragraphs.text: We present a novel tensor network algorithm for computing entanglement entropy in strongly correlated quantum systems. Our method scales as O(χ³D) where χ is the bond dimension and D is the system dimension, improving upon previous O(χ⁵D²) algorithms. We demonstrate applications to the quantum Ising model and Heisenberg chain, finding phase transitions at [EQ1: Tc = 2.269J/kB] and [EQ2: critical exponent ν = 0.63]. The algorithm enables study of previously intractable 2D systems with up to 10⁴ sites.

paragraphs.text: Quantum entanglement serves as a fundamental resource in quantum information processing and characterizes phases of matter beyond Landau theory. The entanglement entropy S = -Tr(ρ log ρ) quantifies quantum correlations but becomes computationally prohibitive for large systems due to exponential scaling of Hilbert space.

paragraphs.text: Tensor networks provide efficient representations of quantum states by exploiting entanglement structure. Matrix Product States (MPS) and Projected Entangled Pair States (PEPS) compress exponentially large state vectors into polynomially scaling tensors. However, computing entanglement measures from these representations remains challenging.

paragraphs.text: Previous work by Vidal established the time-evolving block decimation (TEBD) algorithm for 1D systems. Extension to higher dimensions faced severe computational barriers. Our contribution overcomes these limitations through a reformulation using isometric tensor decomposition.

paragraphs.text: Our algorithm proceeds: 1. Initialize random isometric tensors 2. Sweep through network optimizing local tensors 3. Extract eigenvalues λᵢ of transfer matrix 4. Compute S = -Σλᵢlog(λᵢ). Convergence achieved when ΔS < 10⁻⁸ between sweeps. Implementation uses BLAS Level-3 operations for tensor contractions.

paragraphs.text: For the 1D transverse field Ising model H = -J Σσᶻσᶻ - h Σσˣ, we find the critical point at h/J = 1.00000(1), matching analytical results. The entanglement entropy shows logarithmic scaling S ~ (c/6)log(L) with central charge c = 0.5.

paragraphs.text: Application to the 2D Heisenberg antiferromagnet reveals novel behavior. The entanglement entropy follows area law S ~ L^(D-1) in gapped phases but exhibits logarithmic corrections S ~ L^(D-1)log(L) at criticality. We identify a quantum phase transition at [EQ6: J₂/J₁ = 0.52(2)].

paragraphs.text: Computational performance: Our algorithm processes a 100×100 lattice in 3.2 hours on a single GPU, compared to >48 hours for previous methods. Memory usage scales as O(χ²D) enabling larger bond dimensions.
